person_207.name: William ThomasBrande
person_207.description: Originally trained as an apothecary, Brande became a chemist. With Davy and others founded the Animal Chemistry Club. Lectured on chemistry in various London institutions and, following Davy's retirement succeeded him in his positions at the Royal Institution where he founded The Quarterly Journal of Science. A Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1816-1826; later fell out with Davy. FRSL.

person_520.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
person_520.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

person_421.name: SigmundZois
person_421.description: Wealthy mining magnate in what is now Slovenia. A influential intellectual  and keen amateur mineralogist.

person_244.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
person_244.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

person_349.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
person_349.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

person_562.name: William HenryCavendish-Bentinck
person_562.description: Army officer, MP and first Governor-General of India. The son of a Duke, he enjoyed the courtesy title of lord.

person_563.name: William HenryCavendish-Scott-Bentinck
person_563.description: Politician, MP until 1809 when he succeeded as 4th Duke of Portland.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_226.name: ThomasThomson
person_226.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

person_784.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
person_784.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

person_092.name: NicholasRidley
person_092.description: A supporter of the Reformation and sometime Bishop of London, he was burned in Oxford for heresy in 1555 during the reign of Mary I.

person_144.name: JosephBanks
person_144.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

person_320.name: GeorgeStephenson
person_320.description: Colliery and railway engineer in North East England. He and Davy conducted a virulent controversy over who had invented the miners' safety lamp. He also designed early railway locomatives.

person_560.name: EdwardLascelles
person_560.description: Deriving his fortune from the West Indies, he became large Yorkshire landowner and MP; from 1812, first Earl of Harewood. He was a Proprietor of the Royal Institution. Davy later rented his London house fom Lacelles.

person_012.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
person_012.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

person_575.name: Friedrich vonStadion
person_575.description: German chemist who discovered chlorine dioxide independently of Davy, who met him in 1818.

person_572.name: George O'BrienWyndham
person_572.description: From 1763 3rd Earl of Egremont. Very wealthy collector and agriculturalist who criticised some of Davy's work. FRSL.

person_477.name: JohnNewman
person_477.description: Scientific instrument maker of Lisle Street, and afterwards of Regent-street. Instrument maker to the Royal Institution who made the earliest Davy safety lamps.

person_149.name: CharlesHatchett
person_149.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

person_687.name: BenjaminBevan
person_687.description: English civil engineer, noted for his proof of the equivalence of the elastic moduli of ice and water. He was a principal engineer on the Grand Junction Canal.

person_685.name: Josiah IIWedgwood
person_685.description: Second surviving son of the potter Josiah Wedgwood who took over the running of the business. Served as an MP in the Reformed Parliament.

person_150.name: William HydeWollaston
person_150.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

person_055.name: ThomasDundas
person_055.description: Scottish-born politician and Whig MP, created (1794) first Baron Dundas of Aske. An early Proprietor of the Royal Institution and an Ordinary Member of the Board of Agriculture, he was a landowner, owning Loftus alum works. FRSL.

person_565.name: Robert CavendishSpencer
person_565.description: Naval officer and courtier. As the son of 2nd Earl Spencer he enjoyed the courtesy title of Lord.

person_437.name: Henry ThomasColebrooke
person_437.description: English orientalist and mathematician. He has been described as 'the first great Sanskrit scholar in Europe'. FRSL.

person_356.name: JamesStodart
person_356.description: A London maker of cutlery and surgical instruments. In response to samples sent from India, he developed new, superior kinds of steel. FRSL.

person_567.name: John FredericDaniell
person_567.description: First Professor of Chemistry at King's College London. Developed the first battery that produced a constant flow of electricity.

person_573.name: John AyrtonParis
person_573.description: Physician, chemist and author and member of the Royal Institution. In 1831 published a biography of Davy that John Davy criticised severely in his 1836 biography of his brother. FRSL.

person_715.name: Zoroaster
person_715.description: Zoroaster, also known as Zarathustra, is regarded as the spiritual founder of Zoroastrianism.

person_580.name: Gibbes WalkerJordan
person_580.description: Lawyer born on Barbados who wrote on optics and in defence of slavery. FRSL.

person_052.name: GeorgePearson
person_052.description: Physician and chemist who introduced a new systematic nomenclature for inorganic chemistry in English based on that devised by French chemists and confirmed the effacy of vaccination. FRSL.

person_394.name: BenjaminFranklin
person_394.description: Man of science born in Philadelphia. Inventor, printer, publisher, political philosopher, and a Founding Father of the United States. FRSL.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_824.name: JohnHodgson
person_824.description: English clergyman and antiquary. The Felling pit, site of the Felling Colliery Disaster in May 1812, was in Hodgson's parish. He became a supporter and advocate of Davy's.

place_796.name: Plymouth
place_796.description: Plymouth is a port city in the south-west of England

place_1000.name: Tibet
place_1000.description: Tibet, on the lofty Tibetan Plateau on the northern side of the Himalayas, is an autonomous region of China.

place_653.name: Caldas da Rainha
place_653.description: Caldas da Rainha is a city in Portugal, famed for its sulphurous hot springs.

place_654.name: Wigan
place_654.description: The Wigan coalfield was central in the coal mining of Lancashire from Roman times through the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

place_1397.name: Mumbai
place_1397.description: Mumbai (formerly called Bombay) is a densely populated city on India’s west coast.

place_286.name: Leicestershire
place_286.description: A county in the East Midlands of England.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_573.name: Malvern, Worcestershire
place_573.description: Malvern is a spa town and civil parish in Worcestershire. It lies at the foot of the Malvern Hills.

place_1359.name: Northumberland
place_1359.description: County in the North East of England. It borders Scotland to the north and the county of Cumbria to the west.

place_461.name: Anglesey
place_461.description: Anglesey is an island, and county, on the north-west coast of Wales.

place_320.name: Norfolk
place_320.description: A county in the east of England. The largest settlement is Norwich.

place_492.name: Derby
place_492.description: Derby is an English city on the banks of the River Derwent in Derbyshire.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.
